title: How to Make Teriyaki Sauce

steps.headline: Mix the soy sauce, water, spices, sugar, and honey in a saucepan.
steps.description: Measure out and add 4 cups (950 ml) of soy sauce, 1 cup (240 ml) of water, 1⁄2 tsp (2 g) of ground ginger, 1⁄4 tsp (1 g) of garlic powder, 5 tbsp (75 g) of packed brown sugar, and 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of honey to a saucepan. Stir the ingredients thoroughly until they’re well-combined. You can add more or less honey depending on your sweetness preference.

steps.headline: Turn the stove burner on medium heat.
steps.description: Place the saucepan on your stove-top and slowly start heating up the ingredients over medium heat. Stir the mixture occasionally as it heats up.

steps.headline: Mix the cornstarch and cold water together in a small bowl.
steps.description: Add 2 tbsp (28.3 g) of cornstarch and ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of cold water to a bowl, then mix the 2 ingredients together until the cornstarch dissolves completely.

steps.headline: Add the cornstarch mixture to the saucepan.
steps.description: Make sure the saucepan mixture is heated through, then whisk or stir the cornstarch mixture into it. Keep whisking until they’re thoroughly combined.

steps.headline: Heat the teriyaki sauce until it reaches your desired thickness.
steps.description: Continue stirring occasionally as the sauce heats and thickens, which will take around 10 minutes. Once the sauce has reached your desired consistency, remove the saucepan from the heat. The longer you heat it, the thicker it will get.

steps.headline: Cool the teriyaki sauce to room temperature before serving.
steps.description: If you’re not planning to use it immediately, transfer the sauce to an air-tight container and refrigerate it for up to 1 week. Bring the sauce to room temperature before using it.

steps.headline: Mince the ginger and garlic.
steps.description: Peel the ginger and remove the garlic’s outer skin. Use a sharp knife to mince the ginger until you have about 2 tbsp (28.3 g). Mince the garlic until you have about 2 tsp (8 g).

steps.headline: Chop the scallions.
steps.description: Rinse your scallions under fresh water to remove any dirt and debris. Then, use a sharp knife to chop the scallions roughly until you have about 1/2 cup (118 g).

steps.headline: Mix all of the ingredients in a large bowl.
steps.description: Combine the ginger, scallions, and garlic in a large bowl. Then, add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of soy sauce, 2  tsp (9.9 ml) of dark sesame oil, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey, 2 tsp (8 g) of toasted sesame seeds, and the juice of 2 oranges to the bowl. Stir the ingredients thoroughly to combine them.

steps.headline: Cover the bowl and refrigerate the sauce for at least 1 hour.
steps.description: Snap on an air-tight lid or stretch a piece of plastic wrap over the top of the bowl, then place the sauce in your fridge. The flavors will meld after about an hour. Keep the sauce refrigerated until you’re ready to serve it.

steps.headline: Bring the sauce to room temperature before using it.
steps.description: If you’re not planning to use your sauce immediately, you can cover and refrigerate the teriyaki sauce for up to 1 week. When you’re ready to serve it, allow it to come to room temperature first rather than serving it cold.

text: Cooking Stove-Top Teriyaki Sauce Mix the soy sauce, water, spices, sugar, and honey in a saucepan. Measure out and add 4 cups (950 ml) of soy sauce, 1 cup (240 ml) of water, 1⁄2 tsp (2 g) of ground ginger, 1⁄4 tsp (1 g) of garlic powder, 5 tbsp (75 g) of packed brown sugar, and 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of honey to a saucepan. Stir the ingredients thoroughly until they’re well-combined. You can add more or less honey depending on your sweetness preference. Turn the stove burner on medium heat. Place the saucepan on your stove-top and slowly start heating up the ingredients over medium heat. Stir the mixture occasionally as it heats up. Mix the cornstarch and cold water together in a small bowl. Add 2 tbsp (28.3 g) of cornstarch and ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of cold water to a bowl, then mix the 2 ingredients together until the cornstarch dissolves completely. Add the cornstarch mixture to the saucepan. Make sure the saucepan mixture is heated through, then whisk or stir the cornstarch mixture into it. Keep whisking until they’re thoroughly combined. Heat the teriyaki sauce until it reaches your desired thickness. Continue stirring occasionally as the sauce heats and thickens, which will take around 10 minutes. Once the sauce has reached your desired consistency, remove the saucepan from the heat. The longer you heat it, the thicker it will get. Cool the teriyaki sauce to room temperature before serving. If you’re not planning to use it immediately, transfer the sauce to an air-tight container and refrigerate it for up to 1 week. Bring the sauce to room temperature before using it. Mixing No-Heat Teriyaki Sauce Mince the ginger and garlic. Peel the ginger and remove the garlic’s outer skin. Use a sharp knife to mince the ginger until you have about 2 tbsp (28.3 g). Mince the garlic until you have about 2 tsp (8 g). Chop the scallions. Rinse your scallions under fresh water to remove any dirt and debris. Then, use a sharp knife to chop the scallions roughly until you have about 1/2 cup (118 g). Mix all of the ingredients in a large bowl. Combine the ginger, scallions, and garlic in a large bowl. Then, add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of soy sauce, 2  tsp (9.9 ml) of dark sesame oil, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey, 2 tsp (8 g) of toasted sesame seeds, and the juice of 2 oranges to the bowl. Stir the ingredients thoroughly to combine them. Cover the bowl and refrigerate the sauce for at least 1 hour. Snap on an air-tight lid or stretch a piece of plastic wrap over the top of the bowl, then place the sauce in your fridge. The flavors will meld after about an hour. Keep the sauce refrigerated until you’re ready to serve it. Bring the sauce to room temperature before using it. If you’re not planning to use your sauce immediately, you can cover and refrigerate the teriyaki sauce for up to 1 week. When you’re ready to serve it, allow it to come to room temperature first rather than serving it cold.
